questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

choices.text: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation:  

 

The spirometry graph compares a normal patient's lung function with that of the patient. The normal graph shows an FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) of more than 70%, which is typical in healthy individuals. In contrast, the patient's graph shows a significantly reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of approximately 50-55%, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

 

Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced airflow due to airway narrowing or obstruction, leading to a lower FEV1/FVC ratio. The common obstructive lung diseases include asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, COPD, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: This typically causes restrictive lung disease, not obstructive, and would present with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio but reduced lung volumes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is an interstitial lung disease, which is restrictive. It would show a normal or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced lung volumes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Another interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive patterns on spirometry, characterized by a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced total lung capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is indicative of obstructive lung disease. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the obstructive lung disease associated with this spirometry pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of diarrhea

 

Diarrhea cannot reliably differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms of arthritis because it can be present in multiple arthritic conditions. Diarrhea could indicate:

 

  • Reactive arthritis following gastrointestinal infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis
  • Post-viral arthritis
  • Other forms of seronegative spondyloarthropathies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enthesitis:

 

  • Enthesitis (inflammation at sites where tendons/ligaments insert into bone) is a characteristic feature of psoriatic arthritis
  • It helps differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms like rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option C. Dactylitis:

 

  • Dactylitis ("sausage digits") is highly characteristic of psoriatic arthritis
  • Represents inflammation of the entire digit with soft tissue swelling
  • Helps differentiate from other forms where dactylitis is uncommon

 

Option D. Nail pitting:

 

  • Nail changes are seen in 80–90% of psoriatic arthritis patients
  • Nail pitting is a characteristic finding that helps distinguish psoriatic arthritis
  • A valuable diagnostic feature when present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes are characteristic features that help diagnose psoriatic arthritis. Diarrhea is a nonspecific symptom that can occur in multiple forms of arthritis and cannot be used as a differentiating feature.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm in the following ECG: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal Sinus Rhythm

 

Normal sinus rhythm is characterized by the following ECG features:

 

  1. Regular rhythm with a consistent P wave before each QRS complex.
  2. P waves are upright in leads I, II, and aVF.
  3. A rate between 60-100 beats per minute.
  4. PR interval is normal (0.12-0.20 seconds).
  5. QRS complex duration is within the normal range (less than 0.12 seconds).

 

These features indicate the electrical activity is originating from the sinoatrial (SA) node and is conducted normally through the atria, atrioventricular (AV) node, and ventricles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Atrial Fibrillation: This would present with an irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves. The baseline would appear wavy due to the fibrillatory waves.

 

Option B. Atrial Flutter: Characterized by a sawtooth pattern of flutter waves, usually at a rate of around 250-350 beats per minute.

 

Option D. AV Block: This would show prolonged PR intervals or dropped QRS complexes depending on the degree of block. In complete heart block (third-degree), there is no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal sinus rhythm is indicated by regular rhythm, normal P waves, and consistent PR interval, confirming proper electrical conduction from the SA node through the heart.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text: An individual experiences sudden death, and their ECG reveals ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3 along with right bundle branch block. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brugada syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Brugada syndrome is characterized by a distinctive ECG pattern showing ST segment elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) appearance. This genetic disorder affects cardiac sodium channels and predisposes patients to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially during sleep or rest. The ECG abnormalities can wax and wane over time and may become more pronounced during acute illness and fever. The pattern includes a coved ST elevation followed by a negative T wave in the right precordial leads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Though HOCM is a cause of sudden cardiac death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy, deep Q waves in lateral and inferior leads, and ST-T wave abnormalities. It does not produce the characteristic ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. Aortic valve stenosis: While aortic stenosis can cause sudden death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy and ST-T wave abnormalities in lateral leads. It doesn't cause the specific pattern of ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB seen in this case.

 

Option D. Ashman phenomenon: This is a conduction abnormality characterized by aberrant ventricular conduction (typically RBBB morphology) following a short-long R-R interval sequence. It is not associated with ST elevation in V1-V3 and is not a cause of sudden cardiac death.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brugada syndrome presents with a distinctive ECG pattern of ST elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with RBBB appearance and is an important cause of sudden cardiac death in structurally normal hearts, especially in young adults.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor
Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein

questions.text: Which of the following criteria must be met to perform a Whipple procedure except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

The Whipple procedure is not contingent on pathologic confirmation of pancreatic head tumor prior to surgery. While biopsy may be performed in certain cases, proceeding directly to surgery without tissue diagnosis is acceptable and sometimes preferred when imaging strongly suggests a resectable pancreatic tumor. Preoperative tissue diagnosis is not mandatory when radiographic findings are consistent with resectable pancreatic cancer and laparotomy is planned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of aortic encasement: This is a required criterion for Whipple procedure. Aortic encasement is considered a contraindication to pancreatic resection as it indicates locally advanced disease that would not benefit from surgical resection. Aortic encasement represents unresectable disease.

 

Option C. Absence of liver metastasis: This is a required criterion for Whipple procedure. The presence of liver metastases indicates distant metastatic disease (M1), making the tumor unresectable. Surgery in this setting would not provide survival benefit and is contraindicated.

 

Option D. Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein: This is a required criterion for standard Whipple procedure. Extensive vascular invasion, particularly of the superior mesenteric vessels or portal vein, traditionally defines locally advanced, unresectable disease. Limited vascular involvement may be amenable to vascular resection in specialized centers, but gross invasion indicates unresectability.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While absence of vascular invasion, absence of distant metastases, and absence of aortic encasement are all requirements for Whipple procedure eligibility, pathologic confirmation prior to surgery is not mandatory when imaging strongly suggests a resectable pancreatic head tumor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in Hypokalemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Typically, hyperkalemia would show peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, and possibly a flattened P wave, which are not evident in this ECG.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Would more typically show a prolonged QT interval but lacks the specific U wave features seen in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: This condition would likely show a shortened QT interval, which is not present in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

 

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

questions.text: A young patient presents in a multi-specialty hospital with sudden onset chest pain since 1 hour with ECG showing ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary Angioplasty

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms and ECG findings indicative of an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The presence of ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF confirms the diagnosis. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as primary angioplasty, is the best treatment for STEMI if it can be performed promptly. PCI is preferred because it directly opens the blocked coronary artery, restoring blood flow more quickly and effectively than thrombolytic therapy.

 

Note - If Primary PCI not possible or delayed due to some reasons then thrombolytic therapy (dual antiplatelet therapy) is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots but is considered when PCI is not available or will be delayed.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Another thrombolytic agent, similar to alteplase, used when PCI is not an option.

 

Option D. Dual Antiplatelet therapy: This is an essential part of the initial management of STEMI, involving a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (like clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel). However, it is not the definitive treatment compared to PCI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary angioplasty (PCI) is the best treatment for patients presenting with STEMI, especially when it can be performed within the recommended time frame, as it effectively restores blood flow to the affected myocardium. ​

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability. The diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output

 

In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect

 

  • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)

 

Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect

 

  • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect

 

  • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with headache and seizures. On examination his BP is 220/110 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Labetalol

 

In this case, the patient is experiencing a neurological hypertensive emergency, as indicated by his headache and seizures alongside a high blood pressure reading of 220/110 mm Hg. This condition could stem from several serious issues, including ischemic stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, or hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

The primary objective in managing a neurological hypertensive emergency is to safely reduce the blood pressure. For such emergencies, the first-line treatments typically include IV Nicardipine or IV Labetalol. Given that IV nicardipine is often not available in many Indian hospitals, IV labetalol becomes the preferred option, making it the Ans. in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Nitroglycerin: Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, are generally avoided in neurological emergencies because they cause vasodilation, which can increase cerebral blood flow. This increase in blood flow can elevate intracranial pressure, potentially worsening the patient's condition.

 

Option C. Oral Nifedipine: Oral medications are not suitable for emergency situations due to their delayed onset of action. Immediate reduction of blood pressure is crucial in this case, making oral nifedipine inappropriate.

 

Option D. IV Hydralazine: Although IV hydralazine is an arterial vasodilator, it is not recommended for neurological hypertensive emergencies. Similar to nitrates, it can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure and potentially exacerbate the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neurological hypertensive emergencies, the first-line treatment options for reducing blood pressure are IV nicardipine or IV labetalol, with IV labetalol being preferred if IV nicardipine is unavailable.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

 

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

 

Mutations:

 

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

 

Treatment:

 

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B:  Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism

 

Option C: TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth

 

Option D:  Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heart failure

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF), specifically biventricular failure. The elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are typical signs of right heart failure, which suggests poor venous return management by the heart. Additionally, the presence of crackles at the lung bases points to left ventricular failure, which often presents with pulmonary congestion due to backflow of blood into the pulmonary circulation. This combination points to heart failure involving both the left and right sides of the heart (biventricular failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: While this condition can cause symptoms of heart failure, the presentation would typically include other specific signs such as a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and possibly signs of dynamic outflow obstruction, which are not specifically mentioned here.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation could present with symptoms similar to heart failure; however, a hallmark sign would be a pan-systolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, which isn't mentioned. The systemic signs such as hepatomegaly and ascites are less commonly associated with isolated mitral regurgitation unless it has led to significant heart failure.

 

Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sjogren syndrome

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome:

 

  • Dryness in the mouth and eyes (xerostomia and keratoconjunctivitis sicca): These are hallmark features of Sjogren syndrome, caused by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • Dysphagia: This can occur due to reduced saliva production, making swallowing difficult.
  • Dental caries: Poor saliva production leads to an increased risk of dental caries because saliva helps protect against tooth decay.
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes: Lymphadenopathy can be associated with Sjogren syndrome due to chronic inflammation.

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disease primarily affecting the exocrine glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed connective tissue disorders: These involve features of several autoimmune diseases (such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis) but do not typically present with the classic symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This can cause dry eyes and mouth but is more commonly associated with lung involvement and other systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): This condition involves vasculitis and can affect the respiratory tract and kidneys, but it does not typically present with the primary symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, dysphagia, dental caries, and lymphadenopathy, due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman consults the doctor for the presence of a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and abdomen. Despite anticoagulation therapy, she has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucagonoma

 

Glucagonoma is characterized by the presence of necrolytic migratory erythema (skin lesions), diabetes, and recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The skin rash and the patient’s history are indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulinoma: Presents with hypoglycemia.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma: Associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, causing refractory peptic ulcers.

 

Option D. VIPoma: Presents with watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucagonoma presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, and recurrent DVT.

questions.text: A elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ANCA

 

The clinical features of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of a systemic vasculitis affecting small vessels. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain types of small vessel vasculitis, making ANCA testing the next appropriate step in the diagnostic process. The presence of ANCA, depending on its pattern—c-ANCA typically associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener’s granulomatosis) and p-ANCA with microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss syndrome—helps in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RA factor: Although rheumatoid factor (RA factor) can be elevated in conditions like mixed cryoglobulinemia, which might present similarly, it is less specific for diagnosing small vessel vasculitis compared to ANCA.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg) could be relevant if considering hepatitis B associated vasculitis, but given the clinical presentation, it is less likely the cause of these symptoms.

 

Option D. DIF (Direct Immunofluorescence): While useful in diagnosing immune complex deposition diseases such as immune-complex mediated vasculitis, it is not as directly diagnostic of ANCA-associated vasculitis as ANCA testing itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Vasculitis syndrome/Chap 363

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

 

In patients with HIV and respiratory failure, findings of GGO & cysts within GGO in perihilar locations on HRCT are characteristic for PCP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal pneumonia: This typically presents with more localized consolidations or cavitary lesions rather than the diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities seen in PCP.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal pneumonia: Often manifests as lobar consolidation, which does not match the diffuse pattern observed in the HRCT.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: In HIV-positive patients, tuberculosis may present in various forms including miliary patterns or cavitary disease, especially if the CD4 count is low, but the diffuse ground-glass appearance is more characteristic of PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

 

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes Kinky Hair syndrome, is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene is crucial for the absorption and distribution of copper in the body. The mutation leads to reduced intestinal absorption of copper, resulting in low serum copper levels. This deficiency affects multiple systems, including neurodevelopment and connective tissue maintenance, often leading to severe developmental delay and life expectancy that rarely exceeds early childhood (Children die within 5 years). The condition is also associated with characteristic brittle, kinky hair, and growth retardation.
  • MCC: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This is a liver disorder characterized by chronic jaundice and does not involve ATP7A or copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson's disease: Although related to copper metabolism, Wilson's disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7A, leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is a common hereditary condition that affects bilirubin metabolism, unrelated to copper levels or ATP7A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke's disease is characterized by a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to poor copper absorption and severe systemic deficiencies, notable for its profound impact on early development and survival.

 

Reference - Harrison/Chap 333.

questions.text: What is the axis of this ECG? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right

 

The axis of an ECG is determined by analyzing the QRS complex in the frontal plane leads. Right axis deviation (RAD) occurs when the electrical conduction of the heart is deviated to the right side, which is typically indicated by the following findings:

 

  • Lead I shows a negative QRS complex.
  • Lead aVF shows a positive QRS complex.
  • The overall axis is more positive than +90 degrees.

 

Right axis deviation can occur in various clinical conditions such as right ventricular hypertrophy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary embolism, or can be a normal variant in some individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left: Left axis deviation would show a positive QRS complex in lead I and a negative QRS complex in lead aVF, with an axis between -30 and -90 degrees.

 

Option C. Northwest: This term refers to an extreme right axis deviation (no man's land), which is between -90 and -180 degrees, and is very rare.

 

Option D. Normal: A normal axis ranges from -30 to +90 degrees and would show positive QRS complexes in both leads I and II.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right axis deviation on an ECG is characterized by a negative QRS complex in lead I and a positive QRS complex in lead aVF, indicating an axis of more than +90 degrees​​.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

 

Ivermectin has been extensively studied during the COVID-19 pandemic but has not demonstrated any proven efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infection. Despite creating headlines during the pandemic period, clinical studies have not provided strong evidence that ivermectin reduces the risk of transmission or acquisition of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask: Wearing masks has been proven to be an effective preventive measure in reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by providing a physical barrier against respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vaccine: Vaccines serve as pre-exposure prophylaxis and have been demonstrated to be effective in preventing severe COVID-19 infection and reducing transmission.

 

Option D. Cough etiquette: Proper cough etiquette is an important preventive measure that helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text: 20-year-old female diagnosed with septic shock presents with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg. After receiving 3 litres of intravenous fluids, her mean arterial pressure remains 58 mmHg. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start noradrenaline

 

The next best step is to start noradrenaline (norepinephrine). This patient meets the criteria for septic shock: hypotension with MAP <65 mmHg that persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation (typically 30 mL/kg of crystalloids). 

 

According to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines, noradrenaline is the first-line vasopressor in septic shock. Noradrenaline is an excellent choice because it provides strong vasopressor effects with good inotropic properties and minimal beta-2 activation, which prevents further blood pressure drop. It can be considered a universal vasopressor that works effectively in most types of shock, particularly distributive shock like sepsis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start dopamine: Dopamine can be used as an alternative vasopressor but is not the preferred first-line choice because it can cause severe tachycardia and has arrhythmogenic potential, making it less ideal than noradrenaline.

 

Option C. Repeat crystalloid fluid: The patient has already received adequate fluid resuscitation (3 liters), and the MAP remains <65 mmHg. Further fluid administration without vasopressor support would not be appropriate and could lead to fluid overload.

 

Option D. Start vasopressin: Vasopressin is typically used as a second-line vasopressor according to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines, usually added if the patient doesn't respond adequately to noradrenaline, not as first-line therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline is the first-line vasopressor in septic shock when mean arterial pressure remains <65 mmHg despite adequate fluid resuscitation (30 mL/kg crystalloids).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis because it is characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis with persistent hemoglobinuria, which actually causes significant iron loss from the body. The hemoglobin released into the urine carries iron away from the body, requiring iron replacement rather than causing iron overload. Only PNH patients receiving long-term blood transfusions while on eculizumab treatment may develop iron overload.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Thalassemia Major: Strongly associated with secondary hemochromatosis due to two mechanisms: regular blood transfusions and ineffective erythropoiesis. Even without transfusions, patients with thalassemia major develop iron overload as ineffective erythropoiesis disrupts hepcidin-mediated regulation of iron absorption, leading to increased intestinal iron uptake.
  • Option B. Sickle Cell Anemia: Patients with severe sickle cell disease often require chronic transfusion therapy, leading to iron overload. The repeated transfusions to manage the disease contribute to secondary hemochromatosis over time.
  • Option C. Hereditary Spherocytosis: While less severe than thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis involves chronic extravascular hemolysis. When patients require regular transfusions, they can develop iron overload. Even after splenectomy, transfusion-dependent patients remain at risk for hemochromatosis.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Intravascular hemolysis with hemoglobinuria in PNH causes iron loss, making it the least likely condition to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis, while conditions requiring chronic transfusions (thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia) or causing ineffective erythropoiesis are highly associated with iron overload.

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

choices.text: Renal artery stenosis

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pheochromocytoma

 

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that control heart rate, metabolism, and blood pressure. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

 

  1. Headache: Sudden and severe headaches.
  2. Palpitations: Rapid heart rate.
  3. Profuse sweating: Excessive sweating.

 

In addition to these symptoms, patients with pheochromocytoma often experience episodic hypertension (elevated blood pressure). The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrine, a metabolite of catecholamines.

 

TOC - Start with an alpha blocker, after 24 to 48 hours, add a beta blocker. The alpha blocker of choice is intravenous (IV) phentolamine. Phenoxybenzamine or prazosin can be used as alternative alpha blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Addison's disease: This condition results from adrenal insufficiency and typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Hypotension (low blood pressure) is more common, rather than hypertension.

 

Option B. Renal artery stenosis: This condition can cause secondary hypertension, but it does not present with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating. Additionally, it would not typically elevate urinary metanephrine.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: This condition can cause symptoms like palpitations and sweating, but it would not cause episodic hypertension or elevated urinary metanephrine levels. Instead, hyperthyroidism is more associated with a consistently high heart rate and other systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytoma presents with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating, along with episodic hypertension and elevated urinary metanephrine levels.

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: A lady with mitral stenosis who is bedridden, develops sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, she has a swollen red limb with pain in the calf. What is the clinical diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, who is bedridden with mitral stenosis, presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb with calf pain. These clinical features strongly suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sudden shortness of breath indicates that a thrombus from the DVT has likely embolized to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism. This is a common and potentially life-threatening complication in bedridden patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: This is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, typically secondary to heart failure, and does not present with a swollen, red limb or calf pain.

 

Option C. Cerebral embolism: This would present with neurological deficits, not shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus passes from the venous to the arterial system through a cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). While this could be considered if there were signs of arterial embolism, the presentation here is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in bedridden patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and clinical signs of deep vein thrombosis, such as a swollen, red, painful limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

The patient's presentation includes a constellation of symptoms and laboratory findings indicative of Legionella pneumonia, also known as Legionnaires' disease. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • High-grade fever, cough, and confusion: Common symptoms of Legionella pneumonia.
  • Diarrhea: Gastrointestinal manifestations are frequently associated with Legionella infections.
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray: Legionella pneumonia typically presents with infiltrates rather than consolidation.
  • Hyponatremia (Na: 126 mEq/L): Commonly seen in Legionella due to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).
  • Elevated liver enzymes (AST: 62, ALT: 56): Transaminitis is often observed in Legionella infections.
  • Normal bilirubin and random blood sugar levels: These findings are not specific but do not rule out Legionella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus: Streptococcal pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and does not commonly cause significant gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: This organism typically affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) and presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than focal infiltrates and lacks gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option D. Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and "currant jelly" sputum. It does not typically cause gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Interpret the finding of the ECG given below. (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supraventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with regular rhythm and no visible P waves before the QRS complexes, which is characteristic of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). SVT includes conditions like AVNRT (atrioventricular node reentry tachycardia) and AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular fibrillation: Shows a chaotic, irregular waveform without recognizable QRS complexes.

 

Option B. Atrial fibrillation: Shows an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves.

 

Option D. Ventricular tachycardia: Presents as a wide complex tachycardia, not narrow complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supraventricular tachycardia presents as a narrow complex tachycardia with regular rhythm and absence of visible P waves.

choices.text: In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

questions.text: How does the murmur of severe aortic regurgitation differ from that of mild aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

 

Explanation:

 

In severe aortic regurgitation, the diastolic pressure half-time is significantly shorter (<200 ms) compared to mild AR (>500 ms). This occurs because as AR severity increases, the pressure between the aorta and left ventricle equalizes more rapidly during diastole, resulting in a shorter murmur duration. The characteristic murmur is high-pitched, diastolic, and decrescendo in nature, best heard at Erb's area with the patient leaning forward, but in severe AR it terminates earlier in diastole due to this rapid pressure equalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch - Incorrect because the murmur of AR is characteristically high-pitched regardless of severity, heard best with the diaphragm of the stethoscope.

 

Option B. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type - Incorrect because AR murmurs are typically decrescendo in configuration, beginning loudly and diminishing in intensity as diastole progresses, reflecting the decreasing pressure gradient.

 

Option C. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity - Incorrect because severe AR is typically associated with a louder murmur due to greater regurgitant flow, not softer intensity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The duration of an aortic regurgitation murmur is inversely related to its severity - severe AR produces a shorter diastolic murmur due to more rapid pressure equalization between the aorta and left ventricle, as evidenced by a shorter pressure half-time (<200 ms in severe AR versus >500 ms in mild AR)

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Reduced serum iron level

2.Reduced transferrin saturation

3.Increased total iron binding capacity

4.Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4


Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by reduced ferritin, which is the one of the first indicators of IDA, ferritin indicates the iron stores in the body. Serum iron levels will drop after ferritin levels decrease. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) will increase. Transferrin saturation, a measure of iron and TIBC, will reduce. Transferrin saturation is less than 18%, but less than 20% indicates iron deficiency anemia.

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level: Low iron levels in the blood.
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation: Less iron available for transport.
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC): The body produces more transferrin to capture iron.
  4. Reduced ferritin level: Indicates low iron stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia involves reduced serum iron, reduced transferrin saturation, increased TIBC, and reduced ferritin levels

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common feature of Multiple Myeloma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperviscosity syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

In multiple myeloma, the paraproteins are typically IgG or light chains, which cause hyperviscosity only at extremely high concentrations. Most multiple myeloma patients do not develop serum paraprotein levels high enough to cause clinical hyperviscosity syndrome, making it the least common feature among those listed.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. Bone pain: Incorrect. Bone pain is one of the most common presenting symptoms of multiple myeloma, affecting approximately 70% of patients at diagnosis. The pain results from osteolytic lesions and pathologic fractures caused by increased osteoclast activity.
  • Option B. Normocytic Normochromic Anemia: Incorrect. Anemia is present in about 70% of newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. The anemia is typically normocytic and normochromic, resulting from bone marrow infiltration by plasma cells and inhibition of erythropoiesis.
  • Option C. Susceptibility to bacterial infection: Incorrect. Increased susceptibility to infections is a hallmark feature of multiple myeloma due to hypogammaglobulinemia of normal immunoglobulins and impaired immune function. Patients commonly experience recurrent bacterial infections, particularly with encapsulated organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While bone pain, anemia, and increased infection risk represent cardinal features of multiple myeloma present in most patients, hyperviscosity syndrome occurs relatively rarely and requires extremely high paraprotein levels to become clinically significant.

questions.text: Regarding tumor lysis syndrome, which of the following is NOT a typical laboratory finding?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated calcium levels

 

Explanation:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hypocalcemia (low calcium), not elevated calcium. This occurs due to reciprocal depression of serum calcium in response to hyperphosphatemia, which results from massive tumor cell breakdown and release of intracellular phosphate. The hypocalcemia can cause severe neuromuscular irritability and tetany. Additionally, calcium phosphate deposition in the kidneys can contribute to renal failure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Elevated potassium levels: Hyperkalemia is a hallmark finding in TLS. Potassium is the principal intracellular cation, and massive destruction of malignant cells leads to hyperkalemia. This electrolyte abnormality in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.

 

Option C. Elevated uric acid levels:  Hyperuricemia is a characteristic finding of TLS. Effective treatment kills malignant cells and leads to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids. Uric acid can precipitate in the renal tubules, leading to renal failure.

 

Option D. Elevated phosphate levels: Hyperphosphatemia is typical in TLS. The release of intracellular phosphate pools by tumor lysis produces a reciprocal depression in serum calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome presents with a characteristic tetrad of laboratory abnormalities: 

 

 

along with potential development of acute renal failure. The hypocalcemia is a consequence of hyperphosphatemia due to the inverse relationship between serum phosphate and calcium levels.

questions.text: The murmur of Mitral Stenosis corresponds to which of the following component of the ECG? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) P wave

 

The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to the P wave in the ECG. Mitral stenosis produces a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation. Ideally, this murmur should correspond to the TQ segment or TP segment of the ECG, as this represents the diastolic period when the mitral valve is open and blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle. However, since the TQ/TP segment is not given as an option, the P wave is the best choice because it is located within the TP segment. The presystolic accentuation of the mitral stenosis murmur specifically corresponds to atrial contraction, which occurs during the P wave.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. QRS complex: The QRS complex corresponds to ventricular depolarization and the early part of ventricular systole (rapid ejection phase), which does not correspond to the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis.

 

Option B. T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs during ventricular systole, not during the diastolic period when the mitral stenosis murmur is heard.

 

Option D. ST segment: The ST segment represents early ventricular repolarization and occurs during ventricular systole, not during the diastolic filling period when mitral stenosis produces its characteristic murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The murmur of mitral stenosis is a diastolic murmur that corresponds to the diastolic period of the cardiac cycle, best represented by the P wave among the given ECG options.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. She is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. On examination, the apical impulse is hyperdynamic, and a "pistol shot" sound is heard over the femoral artery. The pulse is collapsing and water hammer-like. Auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation + Mitral regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features suggest a combined valvular lesion with predominant aortic regurgitation (AR) and mitral regurgitation (MR):

 

  • Pistol shot sounds (also called Traube’s sign or pistol shot femorals)
  • Collapsing/water hammer pulse (Watson’s water hammer pulse)
  • Early diastolic murmur – Characteristic of AR
  • Pansystolic murmur – Characteristic of MR
  • Hyperdynamic apex – Seen in volume overload conditions like AR and MR
  • History of rheumatic heart disease, which commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis + Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • MS produces a mid-diastolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • MS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • MS typically causes a tapping apex, not hyperdynamic

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis + Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • No mid-diastolic murmur of MS described
  • Pansystolic murmur indicates MR, not MS

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation + Aortic stenosis: Incorrect because:

 

  • AS produces an ejection systolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • AS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • AS typically causes a sustained apex beat, not hyperdynamic

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of combined aortic regurgitation and mitral regurgitation include:

 

  • Early diastolic murmur (AR)
  • Pansystolic murmur (MR)
  • Pistol shot sounds and water hammer pulse (AR)
  • Hyperdynamic apex (volume overload)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to treat hypertension and edema. It is not specifically known to delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While it helps in managing blood pressure, it does not have the protective renal effects seen with other medications listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: These drugs, such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been shown to provide renal protection by reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by decreasing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to osmotic diuresis and reduced glomerular hyperfiltration.

 

Option B. Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) approved for the treatment of chronic kidney disease in type 2 diabetes. It helps to reduce albuminuria and slows the progression of renal disease.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs, such as losartan and valsartan, are well-known for their renal protective effects. They help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by blocking the effects of angiotensin II on the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:
