Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

choices.text: Complete transection of spinal cord
Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch
Contralateral loss of pain & temperature

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

 

A complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. A complete transection would result in loss of all motor and sensory functions below the level of the injury on both sides of the body, which is different from the hemisection seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome.

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome results from a hemisection or partial lesion of the spinal cord, typically affecting one half. This syndrome is characterized by a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the disruption of different spinal cord tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch: This occurs because the posterior columns (dorsal columns) are affected, leading to loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch on the same side as the lesion.

 

Option C. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature: This results from the damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses to the opposite side of the spinal cord. Therefore, pain and temperature sensations are lost on the side opposite to the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral loss of proprioception: Like the loss of vibration and touch, proprioception is also affected ipsilaterally due to involvement of the posterior columns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of diabetes is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is a biguanide used as a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. One of the most common and significant side effects of metformin is gastrointestinal disturbances, particularly diarrhea. This side effect is due to the drug’s effect on the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause alterations in bowel habits, including watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione and is not typically associated with diarrhea. Its side effects include fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option B. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. While it can cause gastrointestinal side effects, it is more commonly associated with symptoms like indigestion, nausea, and bloating rather than diarrhea.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea and is generally not associated with diarrhea. Its side effects typically include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea as a side effect, making it important for healthcare providers to monitor patients for this gastrointestinal disturbance when prescribing the medication.

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Arterial pH
  2. Venous pH
  3. Venous pO2
  4. Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Arterial pH is the gold standard for acid-base analysis as it directly measures the hydrogen ion concentration in arterial blood, providing a precise assessment of the patient's acid-base status. Venous pH and venous pCO2 can also provide reliable information about the patient’s acid-base status and are often used in clinical settings where arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is not feasible.

 

1. Arterial pH and 2. Venous pH:  Arterial pH: This is the most accurate method for assessing acid-base balance. Arterial pH varies by only 0.03 to 0.05 from venous pH. To estimate arterial pH from venous pH, add 0.03 to 0.05.

 

4. Venous pCO2: To estimate arterial pCO2 (PaCO2) from venous pCO2, subtract 5 from venous pCO2.

 

Venous pH and venous pCO2 can be used in some situations to predict arterial values.

 

Other Options:
 

3. Venous pO2 is not useful for determining acid-base imbalance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial pH, venous pH, and venous pCO2 are used to determine acid-base imbalances.

choices.text: SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of right heart failure, such as pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with maintained contours, suggesting a "money bag" heart appearance characteristic of pericardial effusion. The patient likely has a history of tuberculosis and might have developed constrictive pericarditis, then pericardial effusion and which progressed to tamponade.

 

Additionally, the combination of jugular venous distension and hypotension points towards cardiac tamponade. Pulsus paradoxus, a significant fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade. In this case, the systolic BP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration indicates pulsus paradoxus, confirming tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus bisferians: This is typically seen in conditions like severe aortic regurgitation, a combination of aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation, or hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). These conditions do not match the clinical presentation and X-ray findings of the patient.

 

Option C. Kussmaul breathing: This type of deep and labored breathing is associated with severe metabolic acidosis, such as diabetic ketoacidosis. It is not related to the clinical scenario of pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.

 

Option D. Fine crepitations: Fine crepitations are a sign of pulmonary congestion often seen in left ventricular failure. In the case of cardiac tamponade, there is no pulmonary congestion as the blood is not effectively moving into the pulmonary circulation, thus crepitations would not be present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by pulsus paradoxus, which is a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, often exceeding 10 mm Hg

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.
